subject: Aggregate object fixups
commit_message:
Aggregate object fixups

In the original removal of DictCompat from the Aggregate object, the
aggregate.get(foo, default) calls were changed to getattr(aggregate,
foo, default). This is an incorrect change, because the default of
getattr() is only used if AttributeError is raised. The original get()
call would return the default if the variable was not set, but in order
to get the default with getattr() 'in' has to be used. So now, the
getattr() calls are changed to:

foo = aggregate.foo if 'foo' in aggregate else default

Also, a comment was added for using getattr() on all aggregate fields,
explaining we can do the getattr() and not worry about metadata being
unset, because the compute API always sets it. nova.objects.base also
has a helper method to compare the primitives of two objects to check if
they're equal, so a helper method in the tests were changed over to use
that helper method.

Closes-Bug: #1554617

   we control the versions and code that goes into them, and have our
   own logs for posterity/debugging.

subject: Check tap bridge timestamps to detect local changes
commit_message:
Check tap bridge timestamps to detect local changes

During a quick instance rebuild on Nova, it may remove a tap
interface and then plug it in within the agent polling window.
In this scenario the agent will not realize a device has changed
and will therefore not ask the server for info an subsequently
update its status. This will prevent the notification from being
sent back to Nova that the vif plugging has finished so the
VM will never resume state.

This adds a new timestamp collection method to the common agent
manager interface for devices that is used by the common agent
loop to determine if a device has locally changed.

The linux bridge implementation of it checks the timestamps on the
tap interface's 'bridge' directory, which will change whenever
the tap is added to bridge.

Fix invalidation of tokens stored by DefaultCLI plugin

Keystoneclient Session's "reauth" functionality relies on proper
implementation of invalidate() in auth plugins. Auth plugin needs to
return True if it did anything which could enable successful
re-authentication.
DefaultCLI plugin aims to handle common CLI cases where any combination
of token and/or username/password could be provided. The only case
which has to deal with re-authentication is when both token and
username/password are available. In such cases DefaultCLI when asked to
invalidate should remove old token to enable fallback to
username/password.

This change implements custom invalidate() which fixes re-auth for
clients using DefaultCLI auth plugin.

resuming feature in proxy-server works.

subject: Update default gateway in the fip namespace after subnet-update
commit_message:
Update default gateway in the fip namespace after subnet-update

The gateway does not get updated after a subnet-update --gateway
because the router is already subscribed to the fip namespace.
On a restart, the fip namespace has no subscribers, which causes
the gateway to be created. You shouldn't have to restart the L3
agent in order to update the gateway.

In order for the default gateway in the fip namespace to be updated
after a subnet-update, the underlying code which sets the default
gateway needs to be called even if the router is already subscribed to
the fip namespace.

The bit of code which is responsible for updating the default route has
been refactored into its own method, update_gateway_port, which is then
called after a 'subnet-update --gateway ...'. If the gateway has
actually changed, the default route in the fip namespace will be
updated.

Closes-Bug: #1512858

subject: Allow Horizon setup with external SSL termination
commit_message:
Allow Horizon setup with external SSL termination

This patch allows to use external ssl termination, by setting
'horizon_ssl_external' to True.

The host that does the ssl termination should point to Apache's
VirtualHost *:80 for it's backend and needs to pass on a special host
header to tell the Apache/Django backend whether the url was accessed
with ssl or not.  By default this (http) header is
'X-Forwarded-Proto' and should be set to 'https' when ssl was
involved in the request. Both values are customizable.

When horizon_ssl_external is set to true
- no local ssl sertificate will be generated or installed
- Apache's VirtualHost *:80 will only redirect requests that were not
  over SSL to the https: URL, and will be the main virtual server that
  handles the Django engine.
- Apache gets no SSl enabled VirtualHost *:443 configuration
- Horizon's Django backend gets configured with SECURE_PROXY_SSL_HEADER

Change-Id: I1c654501d0c8573734c52b9c20ba4b5713d667c1
Closes-Bug: #1487433
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

subject: Bump python-troveclient to 2.1.0
commit_message:
Bump python-troveclient to 2.1.0

Trove dropped support for the slave_of argument when creating
instances in 0c94a5bae0aacff7fde9a9742b7d526096e51767.

python-troveclient dropped slave_of support in
a5234f0a07230e0d8195687e033adfe4cc0ad522 which was released
in 2.1.0 (since it's a backward incompatible change, it should
have been a major version bump to 3.0.0, but that's a different
issue).

Since the trove-api no longer supports slave_of, versions of
the client before 2.1.0 won't work with the mitaka version of
the API, at least if they try sending slave_of in the request.

So this signals that the minimum required version of the client
that should be used in mitaka is 2.1.0 so people using the
client at least can't use slave_of in the python API in the
client.

Note that an attempt was made to revert the client change
in I9b3ec6c101a89f30e61fc683808506c404e5474f but because
of the backward incompatible API change in the server, the
revert fails. So unless the API change is reverted, which it
probably won't be, we need to do the next best thing possible
which is move everything forward.

subject: By default, disallow inbound X-Timestamp headers
commit_message:
By default, disallow inbound X-Timestamp headers

With the X-Timestamp validation added in commit e619411, end users
could upload objects with

    X-Timestamp: 9999999999.99999_ffffffffffffffff

(the maximum value) and Swift would be unable to delete them.

Now, inbound X-Timestamp headers will be moved to
X-Backend-Inbound-X-Timestamp, effectively rendering them harmless.

The primary reason to allow X-Timestamp before was to prevent
Last-Modified changes for objects coming from either:

  * container_sync or
  * a migration from another storage system.

To enable the former use-case, the container_sync middleware will now
translate X-Backend-Inbound-X-Timestamp headers back to X-Timestamp
after verifying the request.

Additionally, a new option is added to the gatekeeper filter config:

    # shunt_inbound_x_timestamp = true

To enable the latter use-case (or any other use-case not mentioned), set
this to false.

Upgrade Consideration
=====================

If your cluster workload requires that clients be allowed to specify
objects' X-Timestamp values, disable the shunt_inbound_x_timestamp
option before upgrading.

UpgradeImpact
Change-Id: I8799d5eb2ae9d795ba358bb422f69c70ee8ebd2c

subject: Make install-ironic skip IPA download if create_ipa_image == true
commit_message:
Make install-ironic skip IPA download if create_ipa_image == true

The flag "create_ipa_image: true" may be ignored if the IPA image file
is already present on the local disk.

However, because "download_ipa" defaults to true and runs first, the IPA
image file is always present before the tests to determine whether to
create it or not (unless one specifically sets "download_ipa: false").

This change causes the "create_ipa_image: true" flag to override
the behavior of the "download_ipa" flag.
